abstract.text: Modifies the specified record zones and delivers the results to a completion handler.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The identifiers of the record zones to permanently delete.
The closure to execute after CloudKit processes the changes.
Deleting a record zone is a permanent action that deletes every record in that zone. You can’t restore a deleted record zone.
The completion handler takes a single
parameter that contains either a tuple, or an error if the request fails. For example, when the network is unavailable or the device doesn’t have an active iCloud account.
When present, the tuple contains the following named elements:
A dictionary of saved record zones. The dictionary uses the identifiers of the record zones you specify in
as its keys. The value of each key is a
that contains either the corresponding modified record zone (as it appears on the server), or an error that describes why CloudKit can’t modify that record.
A dictionary of deleted record zones. The dictionary uses the identifiers you specify in
as its keys. The value of each key is a
to indicate a successful deletion, or an error that describes why CloudKit can’t delete that record zone.
For information on a more configurable way to modify record zones, see

abstract.text: Store structured app and user data in iCloud containers that all users of your app can share.
An object that represents a collection of record zones and subscriptions.
Modifies the specified record zones and returns the results to an awaiting caller.
Modifies the specified record zones and delivers the results to a completion handler.
An operation that modifies one or more record zones.
A database partition that contains related records.
An object that uniquely identifies a record zone in a database.
A value that represents either a success or a failure, including an associated value in each case.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
A value that represents either a success or a failure, including an associated value in each case.
